section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter establishes standards for civil money remedies against any provider of health care services or health care supplies or equipment if the Office of the Inspector General finds there are grounds under Health General Article, §2-504.1, Annotated Code of Maryland, to impose a civil money remedy.

para.text: The following terms have the meaning indicated.
Terms Defined.

“Civil money remedy” means a monetary remedy authorized by Health-General Article, §2-504.1, Annotated Code of Maryland, and imposed for a violation of statute or regulation governing the conditions of payment for any service or item for which the provider submitted a claim for payment and received payment.
“Department” means the Maryland Department of Health.
“Hearing” means a contested case hearing as defined by the Administrative Procedure Act, State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Identified recovery” means the total dollar amount of claims identified by the OIG as paid to the provider for a service or item not provided in accordance with applicable statute and regulations.
"Inspector General” means the Inspector General, or the designated Assistant Inspector General, within the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

“Office of Administrative Hearings (OAH)” means the independent unit in the Executive Branch of State government authorized to conduct hearings in contested cases, pursuant to the Administrative Procedure Act and this chapter.
“OIG” means the Office of the Inspector General within the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.
“Violation” means the provision of a service that does not comply with applicable statutes or regulations or both.

A civil money remedy may be imposed against a provider for violation of a State or federal law governing the conditions of payment for any service or item for which the provider submitted a claim for payment and received payment.
It is within the sole discretion of the Inspector General as to whether a civil money remedy is imposed.
A civil money remedy may not be imposed if otherwise prohibited by State or federal law.
A civil money remedy imposed under this chapter:
Is in lieu of full payment or full adjustment of the paid claim and not in addition to repayment of the claim;
May not be less than the federal financial participation share of the identified improper claim amount unless good cause is shown;
May not exceed the amount of reimbursement that the provider received for the paid claim;
Is only available if the provider has not been subjected to a:
Repayment penalty or fine;
Criminal action; or
Civil false claims action under either federal or State law for the same claim; and
May not be imposed if the claim was included in the universe of claims under an extrapolation calculation.
A claim may be made on the basis of more than one violation, but there shall be only one civil money remedy per claim, regardless of the number of violations on which the claim is based.
In determining whether a civil money remedy is to be imposed and in setting the amount of the civil money remedy, the Inspector General shall consider:
The number, nature, and seriousness of the violation or violations;
The provider’s history of compliance;
The efforts made by the provider to correct the violations and any continuation of conduct after notification of possible violations;
The provider’s level of cooperation with the Department or Inspector General as it relates to the review of the claim;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of consumers as a result of the violations; and
Any other reasonable factors as fairness may require.
The Inspector General shall give special consideration to the extent to which the provider’s size, operations, or financial condition:
May have contributed to the violations; and
May affect the provider’s ability to provide care and continue operations after payment of a civil money remedy.
If the civil money remedy is imposed under this chapter, the Inspector General shall issue a written notice and order to the provider that:
States the total amount of the civil money remedies being imposed; and
Includes the following information:
The basis on which the order is made;
Each regulation or statute violated;
The amount of each civil money remedy imposed for each claim;
The number of claims and total value of the claims identified with errors;
The manner in which the amount of the civil money remedy was calculated; and
The provider’s appeal rights.
The notice and order shall be sent to the provider by certified mail.

A provider aggrieved by the imposition of a civil money remedy may appeal the action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Inspector General has the burden of proof with respect to the basis for the imposition of the civil money remedy.
The Office of Administrative Hearings shall render a final decision within 30 days of the hearing.

An order that imposes a civil money remedy is final when the provider has exhausted all opportunities to contest the civil money remedy in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.

After exhaustion of all appeals, a provider shall pay a civil money remedy to the Department within 10 days after the provider receives a final order that affirms the imposition of the civil money remedy unless the Inspector General negotiates and approves a repayment schedule.

If a provider does not pay the civil money remedy to the Department after receiving the final order or according to a negotiated repayment schedule, the State may deduct the amount of the civil money remedy from any sum that is then or later owed by the State to the provider, pursuant to State Finance and Procurement Article, §7-222, Annotated Code of Maryland.
